Cheerleading should be considered a sport because cheerleaders are as fit, or maybe more fit than football players. Cheerleaders should also be counted as athletes since the word athlete means "a person who is trained or skilled in exercises, sports, or games requiring physical strength, agility or stamina." (Dictionary). People can see that cheerleading takes physical strength, agility, and stamina, meeting all requirements to be considered an athlete. Some examples include fast paced floor routines with leaps and jumps, gymnastics-style tumbling, and complex stunts, such as a pyramid building and tossing athletes in the air. People don't see football players doing this yet people still don't think that cheerleading is a sport. Another reason why cheerleading should be a sport is because of support that it gets. One Pediatrician has said "Cheerleading should be designated a sport that it is subject to rules and regulations set forth by sports governing bodies...and school athletic departments. Also, a director of a competerive cheerleading program said "Cheerleading isn't about cheering for the football and basketball teams anymore; it's about competing. The girls and boys who cheer must have the skill of a gymnast, the grace of a dancer, and the strength of a foobtball player. Cheering is more than yelling 'rah rah rah' and shaking pompoms." George W. Bush also served as head cheerleader of Phillips Academy in Andover, Massachusetts, during in his senior in during high school. We all can see that many people support cheerleading in many ways.

Cheerleading should be considered a sport under the Title IX regulations, which state that a sport must have coaches, practices, competitons during a defined season, and a governing organization. The national cheerleading organization, which sponsers regional and national competitions and championship events, is one such governing organization. Also, according to the American Academy of Pediatrics, cheerleading has evoled into a competitive, physically demanding, year-round activity. Cheerleading should also be considered a sport because of its physically demanding nature. According to a director of a competitive cheerleading program, the boys and girls who cheer must have the skills of a gymnast, the grace of a dancer, and the strength of a football player.

You may think that cheerleading is a simple and mindless activity, with girls and guys waving around pompoms and screaming "Rah, rah, rah", but in reality, cheerleading is symbolic of competition, support, and loyalty. To cheer on your team, expressing it in your body language and working to make your support shown is not shallow at all. Over the years, it has become more difficult to become a fluent cheerleader, as it requires physical strength and flexibility, and a mind that can handle frequently being tossed into the air. According to national law, sports must have coaches, practives, competitions during a defined season, and a governing organization. It's main goal is to compete, as the director of a competitive cheerleading program clearly states "Cheerleading isn't about cheering for the football and basketball teams anymore; it's about competing..." Even court rulings have been held over the case that cheerleading is or is not a legitimate sport. During a 2010 district court case in Conneticut (Biediger v. Quinnipiac University), cheerleading was ruled out as not a sport. Later, after examining Title IX, the case was uphel in 2012, which stated that cheerleading needed more organization in order to truly become a sport. Not for lack of strength or need of skill, only that this activity needed a few rules to be counted as a "sport".

First of all, an athlete is anyone who is trained or skilled in exercises, sports, or games requiring physical strength, agility, or stamina. Cheerleaders are athletes because cheerleading requires a substantial amount of strength, agility, and stamina to pull off stunts that would be required to participate in this activity. Cheerleading has become, over the last century, a physically demanding activity. It consists of fast-paced floor routines with leaps, jumps, tumbling, and complex stunts, such as building a human pyramid and tossing athletes in the air. Second, there is a national cheerleading organization that sponsors regional and national competitions. These competitions are built solely around cheerleading much like football, soccer, baseball, etc. There are also cheer camps for young athletes looking to hone and sharpen their skills in cheerleading which is also like any other sport around.

The student's claim about cheerleading has many reasons to why cheerleading is a sport. "An athlete is a person who is trained or skilled in exercise, sports, or games requiring physical strength, agility, or stamina." So basically if you are a cheerleader, you are an athlete because cheerleaders do many physical stunts like hand springs, toe touches, cart wheels and many other stunts. The evidence that the student found is really good evidence to prove that cheerleading is a sport. One evidence would be the director of competitve cheerleading program saying that, "cheerleading isn't about cheering for the football and basketball teams anymore, it's about competing, the boys and girls who cheer must have skills of a gymnast, grace of a dancer, and the strength of a football player, cheering is more than yelling and shaking pompoms." What this evidence is proving is that cheerleaders don't only have cheerleading skills, they have skills of a dancer and skills of a football player. But then some people disagree about cheerleading being a sport, some of the evidence that the student found was the US Court of Appeals stating "that cheerleading needed better organization and clearly defined rules before it could be considered a sport." Another evidence found by the student would be the 2010 district court case in Connecticut, that ruled "that cheerleading was not a sport, according to Title IX regulations."

First, cheerleading is a sport because an athlete is someone who is trained in some sort of exercise or sport that requires physical strength, agility, or stamina. A cheerleader uses all of those things when cheerleading, so they are considered an athlete. There were even famous people such as George W. Bush, former president, who were involved in cheerleading. There is also a national cheerleading organization that sponsors regional and national competitions and championship events, have high school cheer camps, and youth camps. Second, Title IX states that a sport must have coaches, practices, competitions during a defined season, a governing organization, and its main goal to compete. Cheerleading has coaches to teach people how to cheerlead, practices, cheerleading competitions, and has a national cheerleading organization. Therefore, under Title IX cheerleading should be considered a sport even though the district court case in 2010 ruled that it was not a sport, according to Title IX regulations. The reasons why cheerleading is an actual sport are cheerleaders are considered athletes by the definition, there is a national cheerleading organization, and cheerleading follows the regulations under Title IX to be considered a sport.

Firstly, all cheerleaders are athletes, and are capable of many athletic feats. The dictionary definition of an athlete is, " a person who is trained or skilled in exercises, sports, or games requiring physical strength, agility, or stamina." Cheerleading surely requires physical srength, agility, and stamina. In fact, the director of a competitive cheerleading program stated, "The girls and boys who cheer must have the skills of a gymnast, the grace of a dancer, and the strength of a football player." Cheerleaders are just as skilled, dedicated, and powerful as any athlete, and therefore cheerleading is a sport. Even the American Academy of Pediatrics agrees, stating in their report on cheerleading injuries, "over the last century, cheerleading has evolved dramatically into a competitive, physically demanding, year-round activity consisting of fast paced floor routines with leaps and jumps, gymnastics-style tumbling, and complex stunts, such as pyramid building and tossing arthletes in the air." Clearly, a cheerleader's talents are more than enough to make them a top athlete, and to make certain the cheerleading is a sport. Plus, cheerleading has turned into a competitive sport. The director of a competitive cheerleading program proclaimed that, " Cheerleading isn't about cheering for the football and basketball teams anymore; it's about competing....Cheering is more than yelling 'rah, rah, rah' and shaking pompoms." This is true, as cheerleading has become competitive and has evolved from standing on the sidelines cheering a team to becoming a team itself. In fact, Title IX regulations state that a sport's main goal must be to compete in order to be a sport. Well, clearly, cheerleading's main goal is now to compete. In fact, the National cheerleading organization sponsors regional and national competitions and championship events. With all these competitions, cheerleading must be defined as a sport. Just as the American Academy of Pediatrics said, "Cheerleading should be designated [as] a sport."

To begin with, cheerleading has a significant history. Cheerleading was first invented by the male students at the University of Minnesota in 1898, when members of a "pep club" elected people to engage the crowd during the football team's final game of the season. Furthermore, a famous figure - George W. Bush - was head cheerleader of Phillips Academy in Andover, Massachusetts as a high school senior. With such as important impact in tradition, cheerleading deserves to be entitled as a sport. In addition, cheerleading is a sport because of the physical ability required. According to the dictionary, an athlete is "a person who is trained or skilled in exercises, sports, or games requiring physical strength, ability, and stamina." Cheerleading involves all these elements, and the American Academy of Pediatrics clearly points our that "over the last century, cheerleading has evolved dramatically into a competitive, physically demanding, year-round activity consisting of fast-paced floor routines with leaps and jumps, gymnastics-style tumbling, and complex stunts, such as pyramid building and tossing athletes in the air." These components need an athlete with strength, flexibility, agility, and stamina. By all means, cheerleading does not lack any characteristics to be classified as a sport. Lastly, cheerleading can be considered a sport because of the risk involved. According to the American Academy of Pediatrics, who wrote a report on cheerleading injuries, "Cheerleading should be designated a sport so that it is subject to rules and regulations set forth by sports governing bodies... and school athletic departments." In other words, the academy feels that cheerleading should be a sport so that rules can be set upon it. Mentioned by the director of a competitive cheerleading team, cheerleading is more than just cheering "rah, rah" and shaking pompoms - the physical stunts involved expose an athlete to harm, which equal the injury risk of any other sports as well.

In order for an activity to be considered a sport, it "must have coaches, practices, competitions during a defined season, and a governing organization: its main goal is to compete". Cheerleading has become much more than students at the sidelines shaking pompoms and chanting for their school's team. Cheerleaders these days complete physically demanding and complex stunts that require more training, grace, and strength than sports like high school football. It is truly an art form. For these reasons, I believe that an activity requiring so much time and effort should be officially considered a sport. Claims made by the opposing side of the argument would be that cheerleading needs clearly defined rules and organization in order for it to be considered as a sport, but gymnastics and ice skating are both sports that appear at the Olympics, and if asked, many would be unable to state the official rules.Cheerleading is taken very seriously and should be inducted as a sport.

According to a director of a competative cheerleading program, "Cheerleading isn't about cheering for football and basketball teams anymore; it's about more than yelling 'rah, rah, rah' and shaking pom poms." Cheerleading has come a long way to where we are now. It has become a competative sport that many are involved and compete in. As the American Academt of Pediatrics report on cheerleading injuries-"over the last century, cheerleading has evolved dramatically into a competitive, physically demanding, year-round activitiy consistinf of fast paced routines with leaps and jumps, gymnastic style tumbling, and complex stunts, such as pyramid building and tossing athletes in the air." People have also grown fond of the sport, which represents America just as well as football or basketball. In fact, former president George W. Bush served as head cheerleader of Andover Phillips Academy in Andover Massachusettes, during his senior year of highschool. Nowadays, there are many school varsity cheerleading teams, not just for cheering on their football teams. These are oprganized teams that have "coaches, practices, competitions during a defined season, a governing organization, and a goal to compete." Many teams obtain all of these things, therefore should be considered a sport. Aslo, the National cheerleading organization sponsers regional and national competitions and championship events; highschool cheer camps; and youth camps, just like any other sport. My frined last week just went to a national cheer competition in the Virgin Islands to compete for the championships. She had to train all year long for this opportunity just like anyone would for a competition. She went to compete, and all of her hard work paid off when she won the entire competition. "cheerleading is definitely a sport," she says. "It requires intense training, teamwork builiding, and a whole lot of commitment."

My first reason of why cheerleading should be considered a sport is that the defintion of athlete is: a person who is trained ot skilled in exercises, sports, or games requiring phsyical strength, agility, or stamina. If you go by this defintion, cheerleaders are athletes. What do athletes do? They play sports. Next, Title IX supports my opinion. Title IX states that men and women should get equal athletic opportunities. If more men were to cheerlead, many more people would consider it a sport. Title IX says the opposite. Title IX also states that sports must have coaches, practices, competitions during a defined season, and a governing organization. Cheerleading has all of those. Therefore, cheerleading should be considered a sport.

There are many types of sports in the world. Some are legitimate, and others are jokes. In my opinion, cheerleading is a legitimate sport. I think this because It requires strength, agility, and stamina. My initial reason I think cheerleading is a legitimate sport is because you need to have strength. You need to have strength in this sport because you need to do carwheels, backflips, handsprings, and even build a human pyramid. The football/baseball teams have to do just about the same amount of work as the cheerleaders have to. They have to play a sport and run to an area and the cheerleaders have to cheer them on. Clearly, cheerleading is a legitimate sport. Additionally, you need to have agility. If the cheerleaders aren't fast, then they won't be able to do have the stuff they do. If the cheerleaders weren't fast, they couldn't do cartwheels, handsprings, or build a human pyramid. An athlete is defined by the dictionary as "a person who is trained or skilled in exercise, sports, or games requiring physical strength, agility, or stamina." Cheerleading is an intensive sport which requires all of these characteristics: strength, needed for holding people up in a pyramid, agility, for precise movements and tumbling, and stamina, to complete an entire floor routine. The American Academy of Pediatrics's report on injuries in cheerleading states that it "has evolved dramatically into a competitive, physically demanding, year-round activity." Similarly, in Title IX, it states that "(a sport's) main goal must be to compete." Title IX also lists "coaches, practices, comopetitions during a defined season, and a governing oganization"--all things that cheerleading has. What's keeping it from being considered a sport? According to the Connecticut court case Biediger vs. Quinnipiac University, it's the lack of organization and clearly defined rules. However, cheerleading is organized exceedingly well for not currently being a sport. The national cheerleading organization sponsors regional and national competitions, as well as championships, high school cheer camps, and youth camps. As for the rules, the American Academy of Pediatrics's report offers a different perspective: "Cheerleading should be designated a sport so that it is subject to rules and regulations set for by sports governing bodies." Instead of saying that cheerleading needs to have rules to be a sport, maybe we should consider that it needs to be considered a sport to have rules.

The second reason is that cheerleading meets all the requirements to be an official sport. Cheerleading has an official season. Another requirement it meets is that it must have coaches and teams. Finaly, cheerleading should be an official sport, because it is competetive and just as difficult as football, softball, or any other sport. Softball demands practice, so does cheerleading. My first reason to prove that cheerleading is a sport, is that cheerleading fits many of the regulations. According to Title IX regulations, it states, "Title IX regulations-require universities to offer equal athletic opportunities to both men and women; under Title IX, a sport must have coaches, practices, competitions during a defined season, and a governing organization; its main goal must be to compete." Cheerleading does fit all of the requirements above. For example, at Washington High school, in Sioux Falls, South Dakota, the cheer program there has coaches, they practice, they compete, both men and women can do it, and they have a defined season. This shows that cheerleading is a sport. My last reason to prove that cheerleading is a sport, is how strong and talented you have to be to be a cheerleader. American Academy of Peadiatrics report on cheerleading injuries, "over the last century, cheerleading has evolved dramatically into a competitive, physically demanding, year-round activity consisting of fast-paced floor routines with leaps and jumps, gymnastics-style tumbling, and complex stunts, such as pyramid building and tossing athletes in the air." This proves how much skill, talent, and time it takes to be a cheerleader. In conclusion, this shows that it takes the same or more skill to be a cheerleader than in any sport.
